Project Title: Subversive AI
Seeking:: Undergraduate Students, Masters Students, PhD Students
Short Description:
The subversive AI project is fundamentally about employing human-centered research and engineering processes with advances in adversarial machine learning to develop anti-surveillance technologies.

To that end, we have developed a web application — Prixel (a portmanteau of “privacy” and “pixel”) — that allows users to apply extant anti-surveillance AML algorithms (e.g., Fawkes and LowKey) to images they take on their smartphones. Prixel emulates the design language of extant mobile camera applications that allows users to apply filters to their images (e.g., Snapchat, Lensa). It significantly lower the barrier to entry for individuals to explore and experiment with anti-surveillance AML technologies on the photos they take. 

Our goal is to make Prixel ready to field deployment and study. To that end, we are looking for developers who have experience with front-end mobile app development (React Native) as well as those who have experience with improving the speed of machine learning models.
Desired Skills: Web/mobile application development and/or machine learning engineering experience; experience with adversarial machine learning a plus

Project Title: Proof-of-ethics
Short Description:
Today, distributed consensus algorithms in blockchain technologies predominantly rely on proof-of-work or proof-of-stake. In both cases, however, those who participate in consensus are not directly considered with the content of the transactions they are validating, leading to social concerns corresponding with unethical activities. Can we create a "proof-of-ethics" distributed consensus algorithm that codifies ethical principles?

This is a new project that has very little pre-existing work. Interested students should be open to facing lots of uncertainty and ambiguity with project tasks!
Desired Skills: Intermediate - advanced programming skills; specific experience with smart contract languages like Solidity would be great. Would also be good to have knowledge of common ethical frameworks: e.g., utilitarianism, social contract theory, deontology

Project Title: A Grammarly for Privacy
Short Description:
Self-disclosure online brings a lot of tangible social benefit, but the potential privacy intrusions are more abstract and less obvious. For example, sharing that one also attends CMU with a fellow pseudonymous Tartan on reddit  can help forge a friendly bond; however, when paired with the fact that one identified as a non-binary 19 year old from Kentucky in a previous post, that disclosure could uniquely identify oneself. We are working on a project to quantify privacy loss through self-disclosures and are hoping to develop a tool that can provide people with suggestions on how to rephrase self-disclosures in a manner that preserves semantic meaning but reduces privacy loss.

We have a preliminary browser extension and a backend NLP model that can be accessed through an API. We are looking for a skilled developer who can get the extension production ready for field deployment.
Desired Skills: Web and machine learning development skills and/or experience with running user studies to evaluate novel technologies

Project Title: Visual markers of identity in the decentralized metaverse
Short Description: The metaverse is an immersive, 3D virtual environment over the Internet. In the decentralized metaverse, there will be no centralized services like Facebook or Google to provide authenticated user accounts; thus, it is conceivable that every person, place, and thing will have a corresponding public key hash that people will need to verify against. Our goal is to envision the future of visual hashes for identity verification in the decentralized metaverse. To that end, we have created a series of storyboards envisioning scenarios where people in a decentralized metaverse might need to care about verifying the identity of a person, place, or thing. We are looking for someone with experience and interest running interviews and/or focus groups to run this study. We already have IRB approval so you can hit the ground running!
Desired Skills: Qualitative data analysis; experience running user studies

Project Title: Using Large Language Models to Generate Sui-Move Smart Contract with User Instructions
Short Description:
Sui is a project derived from Meta's Libra. Its ainnet launched in May 2023. Sui is a decentralized, permissionless smart contract platform that prioritizes low-latency asset management. Smart contracts on Sui are programmed in the Move language, an emerging language. Due to its scarce training data, current Large Language Models (LLMs) struggle to accurately generate Move language. Our mission is:

1. To collect training data of Move contracts.
2. To enable LLMs to generate, annotate, and modify Move smart contract code according to user instructions through Few Shot Prompt Engineering or fine-tuning LLMs.
3. To write sample test code to assess the performance of different methods.

Our future goal is to enable LLMs to understand Sui Move and guide developers on Sui Move development by integrate it into my previous work, GPTutor. You can find more information about GPTutor in the following links and videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uTNXQuKrnKI, https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01863, https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13896.

In this study, we hope that you have knowledge in blockchain and smart contracts. We would appreciate your assistance in organizing training data, which includes Move smart contract code and task annotations. Additionally, if you could assist us in building and testing different prompts with LangChain, that would be fantastic.

During this process, I can provide guidance on the development of the Sui-Move language, which is gaining popularity in the blockchain industry, with many companies actively seeking Sui-Move developers.

Currently, this project is applying for a Grant, which, if obtained, can be used to pay for your work. Additionally, if any papers are published, you will be a co-author.
Desired Skills:
Python for Data Collection, Blockchain Knowledge
(Optional): Prompt Engineering, Langchain, LLMs Training and finetuning, Sui-Move.

Project Title: Invisible Interfaces: Investigating the Role of Folk Theories in Mediating Human Interaction with Curative and Generative AI
Short Description: search engines like Google, along with algorithm-driven news and content feeds such as Facebook and Twitter, have led to a number of issues, from social isolation to the formation of echo chambers. This is partly due to people's cognitive biases and their limited understanding of technology's capabilities and constraints. As we enter the age of generative AI, the technology's vast knowledge base and its powerful ability to synthesize information have attracted public interest, making it a potent tool for information retrieval, text editing, and content creation. This, however, brings the potential for similar issues to arise, possibly exacerbated by the public's limited grasp of these technologies. This study aims to explore lay users' perceptions and 'folk theories' about generative versus curative AI systems, focusing on how they understand the limitations, inner workings, and benefits of content generated by AI systems. Such insights could guide the design of generative AI application layers, inform trust and safety teams at foundational model companies, and enhance overall user experience and AI literacy. We plan to conduct a mixed-methods study to develop a framework and guidelines that will enhance the development of foundational models and the design of applications based on generative AI.

Project Title: Co-Designing the Future of Transit
Seeking:: Undergraduate Students, Masters Students, PhD Students
Short Description:
Over the past several years, there has been increased investment in automated vehicle (AV) technology for full-size public transit buses, with deployments planned across the country. Yet, operating transit is more complex than the light-duty passenger vehicles for which AV technologies are commonly designed. Buses are significantly larger and operate in highly variable environments with many stops and starts near vulnerable road users (VRUs) such as pedestrians and cyclists. Furthermore, transit operations require supporting passengers and maintaining safety inside the vehicle. Due to both technical and operational challenges, transit vehicles including buses and vans will continue to require skilled human drivers, even as automated vehicle capabilities are incorporated. 

To help maintain transit’s already high level of safety for passengers, it is essential to understand how automation stands to affect the roles and day-to-day tasks of trained drivers. For example, driver assistance automation such as pedestrian warnings and lane-centering has the potential to improve the safety and workload of drivers. At the same time, automation can create new kinds of safety issues caused by the interactions in human-autonomy teams and can intensify work as people primarily take over from automation in the most challenging situations. Therefore, it is crucial to carefully consider how to go about incorporating automation technologies into fleets and to develop new interfaces for transit drivers to work effectively in maintaining safety on the road, and alongside vulnerable road users. 

In this research, we draw on our ongoing partnerships with two major transit unions to develop technologies and interfaces that would help bus drivers in their work, and improve operations. This work will also include passenger-facing design engagement through partnerships with local rider advocacy organizations focused on understanding how these technologies could enhance overall rider experience, with the aim of supporting safety and accessibility. Over the course of the semester, we will conduct workshops and other participatory design activities to imagine and develop co-designed prototypes of new automation technologies and human-machine interfaces to support a more just and accessible future of transit for drivers and passengers.

User Experience Research
Participatory Design
Rapid Prototyping
Qualitative data analysis

Project Title: Tactile Polaroid

Tactile graphics employs raised lines, symbols, textures as well as Braille labels to provide BVI individuals access to visual graphics through touch. Yet, current tactile graphics producing mostly happens in
indoor settings with a dedicated fabrication space, thereby leaving accessing tactile graphics in mobile settings largely under-explored. In this work, we explore one possible future of tactile graphics fabrication where BVI individuals can independently produce and have immediate access to tactile graphics anytime, anywhere.

Students are expected to conduct a literature review on existing text-based motion generation models, perform benchmark testing, and develop an inclusive motion generation model for wheelchair-related motion.

Project Title: Generative AI to train mental health counselors.
Seeking:: Undergraduate Students, Masters Students, PhD Students
Short Description:
Teaching volunteers and professionals the therapeutic skills needed to help clients deal with mental health and behavioral problems is expensive and slow. In addition to receiving didactic materials about the nature of the skills they need, trainees need opportunities to practice these therapeutic skills and receive feedback. This project explores the use of large-language models like ChatGPT to engage trainees in synthetic conversations in realistic conversations with a virtual patient (i.e., a client chatbot) without putting real patients at risk. Our goal is to refine and evaluate a working prototype of our current client chatbot. We will work closely with volunteer support-providers from the online peer-to-peer therapeutic service 7Cups.com or students in counseling programs.

Students who are interested in the project will have the opportunity to participate in the following research activities: (1) conducting formative interviews and observational studies to identify the skills trainees need most; (2) building and testing a virtual patient generator to specify the type of patient with whom trainees will converse, in terms psychological problem  (e.g., job stress, depression, loneliness), personal style (e.g., open or resistant to revealing personal information), or background (e.g., teenage girl, middle-aged male employee);  (3) building and testing a module for providing feedback to the trainee; and (4) conducting qualitative or formal user studies to understand how the conversations with the chatbot can be best used to improve training.
Desired Skills: Needed skills will depend on the research activity the student will pursue. They range from design and empirical skills for the formative and evaluative studies (e.g., interviewing, UX design, data analysis) to more technical skills (e.g., JavaScript or python for prototype development, prompt engineering, LLM training and fine-tuning).

Project Title: VTutor: An Open-Source SDK for Education with Generative AI-Powered Animated Pedagogical Agents
Seeking:: Undergraduate Students, Masters Students, PhD Students
Short Description:
Textual feedback has long been central to education, but adding multimodal feedback—combining auditory and visual cues—can greatly enhance engagement and learning outcomes. Current LLMs are limited to text, leaving multimodal feedback unexplored in education. To address this, we launched the MuFIN project, focusing on Animated Pedagogical Agents (APAs) as virtual tutors – VTutor. Initial efforts using generative AI for feedback videos proved impractical due to high computational demands, with one-minute videos requiring two minutes of processing.

To overcome this, we developed VTutor using Unity, enabling real-time APA feedback with Unity WebGL and Large Language Models (LLMs). VTutor provides human-like feedback via voice and gestures, delivering an interactive, scalable learning experience accessible on any browser. A demo is available at https://vtutor.vercel.app (Note that when open demo, it may take some time to load).

Pilot studies on math and language tutoring showed VTutor improves engagement and retention. Its cost-effective iframe-based integration makes it ideal for K-12 and higher education, demonstrating potential for enhancing learning through generative AI and multimodal interaction.

Project Title: Yiya AirScience: Delivering STEM Education through Radio-based and Phone-based Technologies for Learners in Uganda
Short Description:
Yiya AirScience is a remote learning model that provides radio-based and phone-based virtual classrooms to deliver innovative engineering education for learners in rural Uganda. Many learners reside in low-infrastructure contexts, in which they face numerous obstacles, including lack of educational resources, expensive schooling fees, lack of internet access, etc that prevent them from receiving basic educational experiences. Many African countries, including Uganda, are also heavily influenced by their colonial history, which is reflected in the languages used as a medium of instruction for educational systems, English being a predominant language. However, this educational model presents challenges for students in low-infrastructure and rural areas, where English proficiency tends to be limited.
We are currently in the process of conducting a randomized controlled trial where students are split into two language conditions: English and Leblango, which is a main local language used in Ugandan communities. In this RCT, we are investigating three main questions : 1) Perspectives on Language in STEM: views of students and facilitators on language use in STEM education 2) Language Impact on Learning: influence of instructional language on the student learning experience, STEM motivation, and career prospects 3)Technology's Role in Language Learning: impact of technology on learning effectiveness in English versus local languages.

We are looking for students who are passionate about conducting behavioral research in education and qualitative data analysis, with a strong focus on thematic analyses and in-depth exploration of qualitative data, including interview transcripts, discussion-based conversations, and other data sources.
Desired Skills: We are looking for students who are passionate about conducting behavioral research in education and qualitative data analysis, with a strong focus on thematic analyses and in-depth exploration of qualitative data, including interview transcripts, discussion-based conversations, and other data sources.

Project Title: Privacy Mirror
Seeking:: Undergraduate Students, Masters Students, PhD Students
Short Description:
A defining dilemma of modern social media is helping users balance the social benefits they reap through online self-disclosure versus the privacy risks associated with those disclosures. Part of the challenge is that while the benefits of self-disclosure are often apparent, the harms are abstract and difficult to reason about which can lead to disclosures that people regret. 

Privacy mirror is a chrome browser based plugin we are building with the intentions to empower users of SNS platforms through improving their awareness of self-disclosures in their posts that may pose a threat to their privacy. This project insights  from HCI and privacy with  NLP technology to highlight potentially harmful self-disclosures in users’ posts as they’re drafting them, and empower them in crafting alternative phrasings that offer more protection of their privacy while still allowing them to reap the benefits of online self-disclosures.  

The student on this project will help front and backend development of the plugin itself. As part of this role, this independent study student will work to implement the UI and UX of the app based on existing wireframes, and help bring the plugin to a minimum viable product state. The student in this role may also have an opportunity to conduct evaluations of this intervention.

Project Title: Understanding the Opportunities and Challenges of Designing Mutual Theory of Mind in Human-AI Interactions
Short Description: AI systems are being increasingly equipped with Theory-of-Mind-like capabilities to meet people’s social expectations of AI while they assume increasingly diverse social roles in our society. Theory of Mind (ToM) is a basic social and cognitive human capability of attributing mental states such as beliefs, emotions, knowledge, and plans to oneself and others based on explicit and latent behavioral and verbal cues. AI systems equipped with ToM-like capabilities present great promises in enhancing the efficiency, naturalness, and human experiences in human-AI communication, collaboration, and interactions. For example, in human-AI teams, AI systems with ToM-like capabilities can infer human partners’ intentions, plans, and knowledge state to provide timely and necessary information for task completion, as well as accounting for irrational human behaviors that deviate from the original plan. As such AI systems display ToM-like capabilities, humans are also leveraging our own ToM capability to make inferences about the AI’s internal states. This forms the emerging phenomenon of Mutual Theory of Mind (MToM), where both the human and the AI possess ToM-like capabilities to continuously infer and attribute mental states to each other during an interaction. While a successful MToM depicts a future of human-AI interaction that is adaptive, continuous, constructive, and natural, the specific challenges and opportunities of designing and building towards MToM in human-AI interaction have not been explored. This project aims at leveraging design and qualitative research methods to envision the future of MToM in human-AI interaction with multiple stakeholders such as users and industry AI practitioners. This project seeks to identify the opportunities and challenges of MToM from different stakeholders’ unique perspectives and experiences, including the potential responsible AI consequences of MToM in human-AI interaction. Findings will contribute to a design guideline and future agenda for designing MToM in the next generation of human-AI interaction.
Desired Skills: Design methods (e.g., storyboarding), qualitative research methods (e.g., interviews, surveys).

Project Title: AI Variety Cards: Supporting Responsible AI Ideation Across Various AI Model Types

The goal of this project is to develop a novel Responsible AI toolkit – AI Variety Cards – to help AI product teams better understand and navigate the advantages, limitations, and ethical considerations of various AI models. This toolkit aims to facilitate more ethical decision-making by guiding AI product teams to select models that balance feasibility, technical viability, stakeholder desirability, and potential harms, contributing to our long-term research vision of developing and assessing innovative tools, processes, and methods that support the Responsible AI (RAI) ideation. By promoting ethical decision-making in AI model selection, our research will also help inform policies focused on transparency, fairness, and accountability in AI innovation, ensuring that AI systems are developed responsibly from the early stages.

Project Title: Replacing Homework with Effort-based Practice for Higher Education: A New Course Structure for Mathematics Education
Short Description:
We propose a transformative structure of CMU’s 15-151 & 21-128 by replacing traditional homework with a system that measures practice time on knowledge components. Rather than submitting written proofs for weekly grades, students will devote a fixed number of hours (e.g., six) each week—either face-to-face with TAs or online—to practicing core concepts at their own pace. We will use VTutor to enable real-time monitoring through AI-supported screen sharing, collaborative tutor oversight, and an engaging on-screen avatar. This redesign addresses three urgent issues in CMU courses: (1) the surge in large language model (LLM) use for automatically generating homework solutions, which erodes genuine learning and academic integrity; (2) heightened student anxiety over difficult, high-workload coursework; and (3) the struggle of conventional course structures to challenge a student body with widely varying levels of prior experience.

By shifting the emphasis from correctness-based grading to ongoing, individualized practice, we anticipate deeper conceptual mastery, heightened intrinsic motivation, and decreased stress across the semester. Rather than grading homework correctness, which can be easily achieved by the use of AI, this structure evaluates students based on consistent, meaningful engagement aligned with their proficiencies. After piloting and assessing this approach in the summer and fall term, we aim to adapt and expand it as a foundational blueprint for personalized, adaptive learning in other courses.

Project Title: Generating Augmented Reality Interfaces Leveraging User Flows
Short Description:
User interfaces for Augmented Reality (AR) are currently unpleasant to interact with. In particular, their limited field of view, resolution, and input make interactions with traditional interfaces cumbersome. For instance, consider browsing the New York Times with a small 70-degree view window. Because the display limits the amount the user can see at once, they either have to zoom out of the window, which makes the text more difficult to read, or slowly scan through parts of the window bit by bit. Both cases can quickly result in eye and neck strain. 

In this project, we investigate the feasibility of automatically adapting interfaces for AR leveraging generative models. To accommodate the smaller field of view, we propose decomposing an interface into its constituent elements and only showing to the user a relevant subset. To determine how exactly we should decompose an interface into its constituent elements and what to show in the final AR interface, we propose leveraging existing knowledge on user flows (i.e., a user's journey to complete specific tasks within an application or service). 

This project will result in a collection of AR interface designs and a working system, contributing to knowledge on how future interfaces should be designed for glasses-based form factors.

You will work closely with a PhD student to help bring this system to life—either by implementing physics-driven motion behaviors, building the gesture interaction layer, or designing the layout management logic. Depending on your interests and skills, you might prototype dynamic UI components in Unity, experiment with movement smoothing and constraint logic, or create demo scenes that showcase expressive motion in XR. Project Title: Emotion-Driven Interactions: Designing Adaptive XR Interactions for Matching and Counteracting User Emotions
Exploring Body Duplication in VR for Productivity and Self-Guidance
Empathy Game Research
Short Description:
This is a research project to study how a game can facilitate collective empathy towards people living with poverty. The game simulates the stress and pressure of overcoming poverty in the U.S. by making choices about real-life situations.  

The Research Assistant will work alongside the research team and a professional game designer to execute a study on the game’s impact on players. This study is already IRB approved. If desired, the Research Assistant may continue to work with the research team through data analysis and writing an academic paper. Research Assistant will also receive monthly mentorship from a faculty member in HCII with game design and research expertise.
Desired Skills:
Technical Skills: Comfort with project tools such as Slack, Google Suites, Figma.
Research Skills: Responsible for recruiting participants, coordinating play sessions, and managing interview data. 
Problem-Solving: Ability to work independently and identify when additional support is needed. 
Communication Skills: Excellent verbal and written communication skills to interact with interviewees and team members. 
Organizational Skills: Ability to manage time, prioritize tasks, and maintain accurate records.
